pageProps.contentHtml:
Week 0 Discussion Notes

Since this discussion was before the first lecture, we just reviewed some trigonometry and integration.

Example 1.

Calculate ∫sec⁡3xtan⁡x dx\displaystyle \int \sec^3 x \tan x \,\diff{x}∫sec3xtanxdx.
Solution.

We will solve this in two different ways.

Method 1: u=sec⁡x  ⟹  du=sec⁡xtan⁡x dxu = \sec x \implies \diff{u} = \sec x \tan x \,\diff{x}u=secx⟹du=secxtanxdx.

∫sec⁡3xtan⁡x dx=∫(sec⁡2x)(sec⁡xtan⁡x) dx=∫u2 du=13u3+C=13sec⁡3x+C\begin{aligned} \int \sec^3 x \tan x \,\diff{x} &= \int \p{\sec^2 x} \p{\sec x \tan x} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \int u^2 \,\diff{u} \\ &= \frac{1}{3} u^3 + C \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3} \sec^3 x + C} \end{aligned}∫sec3xtanxdx​=∫(sec2x)(secxtanx)dx=∫u2du=31​u3+C=31​sec3x+C​​

Method 2: u=cos⁡x  ⟹  du=−sin⁡x dxu = \cos x \implies \diff{u} = -\sin x \,\diff{x}u=cosx⟹du=−sinxdx.

∫sec⁡3xtan⁡x dx=∫sin⁡xcos⁡4x dx=−∫duu4=−(−13u−3)+C=131cos⁡3x+C=13sec⁡3x+C\begin{aligned} \int \sec^3 x \tan x \,\diff{x} &= \int \frac{\sin x}{\cos^4 x} \,\diff{x} \\ &= -\int \frac{\diff{u}}{u^4} \\ &= -\p{-\frac{1}{3}u^{-3}} + C \\ &= \frac{1}{3} \frac{1}{\cos^3 x} + C \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3} \sec^3 x + C} \end{aligned}∫sec3xtanxdx​=∫cos4xsinx​dx=−∫u4du​=−(−31​u−3)+C=31​cos3x1​+C=31​sec3x+C​​
Example 2.

Calculate ∫sec⁡4x dx\displaystyle \int \sec^4 x \,\diff{x}∫sec4xdx.
Solution.

Recall the identity tan⁡2x+1=sec⁡2x\tan^2 x + 1 = \sec^2 xtan2x+1=sec2x. This gives

∫sec⁡4x dx=∫(tan⁡2x+1)sec⁡2x dx.\int \sec^4 x \,\diff{x} = \int \p{\tan^2 x + 1} \sec^2 x \,\diff{x}.∫sec4xdx=∫(tan2x+1)sec2xdx.

Let u=tan⁡x  ⟹  du=sec⁡2x dxu = \tan x \implies \diff{u} = \sec^2 x \,\diff{x}u=tanx⟹du=sec2xdx. Then

∫sec⁡4x dx=∫(tan⁡2x+1)sec⁡2x dx=∫(u2+1) du=13u3+u+C=13tan⁡3x+tan⁡x+C.\begin{aligned} \int \sec^4 x \,\diff{x} &= \int \p{\tan^2 x + 1} \sec^2 x \,\diff{x} \\ &= \int \p{u^2 + 1} \,\diff{u} \\ &= \frac{1}{3} u^3 + u + C \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3} \tan^3 x + \tan x + C}. \end{aligned}∫sec4xdx​=∫(tan2x+1)sec2xdx=∫(u2+1)du=31​u3+u+C=31​tan3x+tanx+C​.​
Example 3.

Calculate ∫tan⁡2x dx\displaystyle \int \tan^2 x \,\diff{x}∫tan2xdx.
Solution.

Using the same identity as in Example 2, we get

∫tan⁡2x dx=∫sec⁡2x−1 dx=tan⁡x−x+C.\int \tan^2 x \,\diff{x} = \int \sec^2 x - 1 \,\diff{x} = \boxed{\tan x - x + C}.∫tan2xdx=∫sec2x−1dx=tanx−x+C​.
